title: Temperature
text:
Explore the effects of changing the air temperature (test).

Interpretation: increasing air temperature, increases canal temperature (surface). Not particularly insightful!



How has increasing the air temperature of the environment influenced the water temperature?

In the daytime, most cooling during spring, less during summer
The effect of increasing air temperature (on the effects of canals of air temperature) seems relatively small, but appears to decrease daytime cooling slightly.


When it comes to warming water, solar intensity plays a significantly greater role than air temperature, as the direct absorption of sunlight by the water surface is the primary driver of heat gain, while air temperature primarily affects heat transfer through convection, which is usually less impactful than the direct solar radiation absorption. (AI)
See https://doi.org/10.2166/nh.2021.148
Ultimately, air temperature likely to have a small effect (convection).
Not 100% sure on this… but whatever

title: Results
text:
Effects on air temperature


2022 was the warmest year on record in the UK, in series stretching back to 1884 ( Kendon et al. 2023) and 1659 (Manley et al. 1974), with the summer period marked by extreme heatwaves on 15–17 June, 17–19 July and 9–15 August. Of these, the 17–19 July heatwave resulted in the UK’s highest ever recorded temperature, at 40.3°C (Witze 2024).

Is there evidence of these heatwaves in the series? What does this do to air temperature?

As above, but here showing the effects at night.



What effect do canals have an overnight temperatures? How does this change seasonally?

title: Model
text:
Approach
It begins by creating inital temperatures and energy values for layers of the water column, then models these through time based on different energy exchanges (convective, radiative, conductive).

title: Area
text:
When calculating the effects of the water on the temperature of the surrounding environment, we need to determine the size of the environment we are modelling i.e., are we estimating the change in temperature in a 1 km2 area around the canal, a 100 m2 area, or for the whole city?
Previous studies have shown that small water bodies can have a measurable effect within 30 - 40 m (Hathaway and Sharples, 2012, Park et al. 2019) and potentially up to 60 m (Kim et al. 2014). In our model, we therefore use a 100-m wide corridor around the canal (10-m tall), which is equivalent to 50-m buffer on all sides.
Buffering is a standard GIS operation found in almost all relevant software and code e.g., in ArcGIS, QGIS or using Shapely and Geopandas.
However, it is not an appropriate approach for our model because of the importance of shape complexity.
To illustrate, let’s look at two canals in the city centre, one on the Manchester Bolton and Bury Canal (mabc_8) and the other on the Bridegwater Canal (bc_83).


Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook


These canal sections have very similar areas of 2113.67 m2 (mbabc_8) and 2069.48 m2 (bc_83).
However, because of differing shape complexity, using a standard buffer e.g., shape.buffer(50) results in quite different buffer areas of 26218.45 m2 (mbabc_8) and 22832.39 m2 (bc_83).
For mbabc_8, the buffer area is approximately 12.40× larger, but only 11.03× for bc_83.
For most spatial queries, shape complexity isn’t an important issue. In our case though, this is a problem because the magnitude of the temperature effect is partly dependent on the size of the area we are modelling for i.e., the same energy flux averaged over a larger area = a smaller temperature effect, whereas averaged over a smaller area = a larger temperature effect.
The underlying principle is that if bc_83 and mbabc_8 were identical in water temperature and energy storage, then they should have an identical effect on the surrounding environment in our non-spatial model. Using a standard buffer would not produce this behaviour, as different temperature effects would be produced due to modelling of different size areas (12.40× vs. 11.03×)!
To account for this, we can use a shape-normalised buffer, which involves creating a circle of the same area of the canal, and then buffering by the desired amount.



A shape-normalised buffer


The advantage of this approach is that the buffered area increases linearly with the area of the canal, which is shown below for the full dataset of modelled canals in the UK and Ireland, where A shows canal area (x) compared to a standard buffer area (y), and B shows canal area (x) compared to a shape-normalised buffer area (y):



Standard vs. shape-normalised buffers

Changing canal area
Using this approach, we can then start to investigate how changing the area of the canal influences the magnitude of the temperature effect.
Again, we will use rc_9 as an example, re-running the model with different areas (×0.5, ×1.5, ×2.0, ×3.0). This produces the following results, which are the average daytime temperature effect across the year:

title: GEOG70812: Local Scale Mitigation
text:
Introductory text, describing the overall context.

Explore Manchester’s canal network below, and the buildings within 100 m.



Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook


In today’s practical, we’re going to explore the model, considering its structure, validation and initial results. We’ll also explore the sensitivity of the model to changing inputs, including the degree of shading and canal area, and model performance under changing climate.
To finish, there is a short formative quiz to test your knowledge.

title: Quiz
text:
Answer the following questions:





What effect do canals have on daytime temperatures?

Cooling No effect Warming







What effect do canals have on nighttime temperatures?

Cooling No effect Warming







Which season typically sees the greatest daytime effects on temperature?

Winter Spring Summer Autumn







Which season typically sees the greatest nighttime effects on temperature?

Winter Spring Summer Autumn







How does increasing shading influence the effect of canals on air temperatures?

Increased cooling No effect Reduced cooling







How does increasing canal area influence the effect of canals on air temperatures?

Increased cooling No effect Reduced cooling








If you’ve been through the practical and want to explore some of this further, one thing we might to reflect on is the accuracy of our shading calculations. In our model, we use an existing package called pybdshadow, designed specifically for generating building shadows, and base our calculations based on building geometries (footprints, heights) from the Ordnance Survey MasterMap Topography layer.
To illustrate the typical outputs, you can download the canal geometry for one feature of the Ashton Canal (ac1_6), the nearby building geometries, and the shadows produced at a specific datetime (2022-01-01 09:45:00). [Note: shadows are only produced for buildings in the solar direction, for computational ease]
Here’s the ShadeApp output: https://shademap.app/@53.48025,-2.22222,16.00077z,1735724716321t,0b,0p,0m!1735719966854!1735747267074# Here’s the suncalc output: https://www.suncalc.org/#/53.4794,-2.2221,17/2022.01.01/09:45/27.5/3

title: Shading
text:
To explore the effects of shading, let’s look at one section of the Bridgewater Canal, Manchester.
This is a relatively large canal, but with few buildings in the surrounding area (Cornbrook). As a former industrial area, there is development potential.



Bartholomew map of Cornbrook (1900). Source


Here is the canal today, and nearby building geometries.


Make this Notebook Trusted to load map: File -> Trust Notebook



Explore the effects of adding shading to water temperature (test).

Also run with rc_17, rc_9



How has adding shading to the environment influenced the water temperature?

Here we have the net change in air temperature, associated with water only (reference material excluded).
0 is the unshaded model
Then we add the actual shading for bc_277 (minimal effect)
We also re-run using the shading parameters for a nearby canal section on the Rochdale Canal (rc_9), which is a proxy for the shading that could occur if this area was extensively developed
We also run with the (unrealistic) full shading (canal entirely shaded)
